revisions:
[{'created': '2018-03-07 10:12:51.000000000', 'message': "ovs-fw: pass NEW state for egress traffic down the pipeline

In case where Neutron logical port is placed directly to hypervisor,
hypervisor does a conntrack lookup before packets reach OVS integration
bridge. This patch takes only the NEW state as hypervisor won't perform
a lookup in correct zone for given tenant network.

The patch doesn't cover this case with test as it's impossible to do so
with tempest. The good candidate is fullstack framework which might be
done as a followup.

Change-Id: Ia4f524adce2b5ee6d98d3921cfb03d56ad6d0813
Closes-bug: #1747082
"}, {'created': '2018-03-09 09:55:43.000000000', 'message': "ovs-fw: Clear conntrack information before egress pipeline

In case where Neutron logical port is placed directly to hypervisor,
hypervisor does a conntrack lookup before packets reach OVS integration
bridge. This patch drops such conntrack information and does its own
lookup in correct zone associated with port's network.

The patch doesn't cover this case with test as it's impossible to do so
with tempest. The good candidate is fullstack framework which might be
done as a followup.

Change-Id: Ia4f524adce2b5ee6d98d3921cfb03d56ad6d0813
Closes-bug: #1747082
"}, {'created': '2018-03-09 11:14:58.000000000', 'message': "ovs-fw: Clear conntrack information before egress pipeline

In case where Neutron logical port is placed directly to hypervisor,
hypervisor does a conntrack lookup before packets reach OVS integration
bridge. This patch introduces a new base table that is placed before
egress pipeline, all packets in this table are not tracked as the
transient table drops conntrack information if present.

That means all packets in egress pipeline are not tracked and ovs
firewall can do a lookup in correct zone. As for ingress pipeline, it
distinguishes between tracked - which are packets coming from egress
pipeline, and not tracked, which are inbound packets coming not from a
local port.

The patch doesn't cover this case with test as it's impossible to do so
with tempest. The good candidate is fullstack framework which might be
done as a followup.

Change-Id: Ia4f524adce2b5ee6d98d3921cfb03d56ad6d0813
Closes-bug: #1747082
"}, {'created': '2018-03-09 15:23:03.000000000', 'message': 'ovs-fw: Clear conntrack information before egress pipeline

In case where Neutron logical port is placed directly to hypervisor,
hypervisor does a conntrack lookup before packets reach OVS integration
bridge. This patch introduces a rule with high priority that is placed
at the beginning of the egress pipeline. This rule removes conntrack
information from all packets if conntrack information is present. Then
packets continue in the egress pipeline.

That means all packets in egress pipeline are not tracked and ovs
firewall can do a lookup in correct zone. As for ingress pipeline, it
distinguishes between tracked - which are packets coming from egress
pipeline, and not tracked, which are inbound packets coming not from a
local port.

Change-Id: Ia4f524adce2b5ee6d98d3921cfb03d56ad6d0813
Closes-bug: #1747082

pipeline, and not tracked, which are inbound packets coming not from a
local port.

Change-Id: Ia4f524adce2b5ee6d98d3921cfb03d56ad6d0813
Closes-bug: #1747082
'}]
commit_message:
ovs-fw: Clear conntrack information before egress pipeline

In case where Neutron logical port is placed directly to hypervisor,
hypervisor does a conntrack lookup before packets reach OVS integration
bridge. This patch introduces a rule with high priority that is placed
at the beginning of the egress pipeline. This rule removes conntrack
information from all packets if conntrack information is present. Then
packets continue in the egress pipeline.

That means all packets in egress pipeline are not tracked and ovs
firewall can do a lookup in correct zone. As for ingress pipeline, it
distinguishes between tracked - which are packets coming from egress
pipeline, and not tracked, which are inbound packets coming not from a
local port.

Change-Id: Ia4f524adce2b5ee6d98d3921cfb03d56ad6d0813
Closes-bug: #1747082

commit_message:
Implement clouds.yaml for root user

The use of clouds.yaml from the zuul user does not
work for swift due to the mess of delegation and
become. In this patch we ensure that it is also
there for the root user so that the role test can
pass.

This issue does not apply to the integrated repo.

Change-Id: Ia152f9c24e4965f89d9477f4e343428bb04b3c59

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-07-18 03:41:23.000000000', 'message': 'Use trigger-readthedocs role

This role has been added to trigger readthedocs via their new API.

It requires the rtd_username and rtd_password as defined in the new
secret.  Projects will need to add the "openstackci" user as an admin
on their project so it can trigger the build.

Change-Id: Ic34ea5ead26a477a1cc5f8b25fd2ce1949c1dc13
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/579434
'}, {'created': '2018-07-19 03:26:50.000000000', 'message': 'Add trigger-readthedocs-webhook job

This job is to trigger readthedocs via their new API

The old API was quite simple in that anyone could hit the end-point
and trigger a new build.  We now require authentication and a unique
webhook id for each project we wish to update.

This leaves us with a bit of an issue with the "docs-on-readthedocs"
job template, which adds the "trigger-readthedocs" job to the
post/publish pipelines for a project.

If projects wish, they can directly use the new "trigger-readthedocs"
role (from the dependent change) and provide their username/password
or webhook token directly from a secret in their project playbook.

However, this proposes retaining delegation of the build via infra
methods.  Projects that wish to use it then don't have to worry about
managing new jobs or their secrets, and gain some benefits in having a
backup that the infra team can help manage the project easily
(changing, deleting, renaming etc).

Thus to continue using the "docs-on-readthedocs" template, projects
will need to do three things

1) add openstackci user as an admin of their project
2) generate an webhook via the "Integrations" dashboard page on the
   RTD project
3) provide the id from that webhook URL to this playbook

This webhook id is not private; it is useless without authentication
(it appears to be a global monotonically increasing integer for each
webhook generated).  Thus we can store it in plaintext in the job
playbook.

A secret is added for the openstackci RTD user, which is then used to
ping the API endpoint via the new role in the dependent change.

Change-Id: Ic34ea5ead26a477a1cc5f8b25fd2ce1949c1dc13
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/579434
'}, {'created': '2018-07-27 06:05:44.000000000', 'message': 'Add trigger-readthedocs-webhook job

This job is to trigger readthedocs via their new API

The old API was quite simple in that anyone could hit the end-point
and trigger a new build.  We now require authentication and a unique
webhook id for each project we wish to update.

If projects wish, they can directly use the new "trigger-readthedocs"
role (from the dependent change) and provide their username/password
or webhook token directly from a secret in their project playbook.

However, we have recently added the ability to set variables in
projects and project-templates.  This means we can retain delegation
of the build via infra methods.  Projects that wish to take this route
don't have to worry about managing new jobs or their secrets, and gain
some benefits in having the openstackci user as a backup admin.

To continue using the "docs-on-readthedocs" template, projects will
need to do three things

1) add openstackci user as an admin of their project
2) generate an webhook via the "Integrations" dashboard page on the
   RTD project
3) provide the id from that webhook URL to this playbook (likely via
   the docs-on-readthedocs template; see
   I3b65813671961d07c0a743685c537ad1df4bf68 and the included example)

This webhook id is not private; it is useless without authentication
(it appears to be a global monotonically increasing integer for each
webhook generated).

A secret is added for the openstackci RTD user, which is then used to
ping the API endpoint via the new role in the dependent change.

Change-Id: Ic34ea5ead26a477a1cc5f8b25fd2ce1949c1dc13
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/579434
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/584230

'}, {'created': '2018-07-30 01:36:30.000000000', 'message': 'Add trigger-readthedocs-webhook job

This job is to trigger readthedocs via their new API

The old API was quite simple in that anyone could hit the end-point
and trigger a new build.  The v2 API now requires authentication and a
unique id for each project we wish to update.

If projects wish, they can directly use the new "trigger-readthedocs"
role (from the dependent change) and create their own jobs, providing
their username/password or webhook authentication token directly from
a secret in their project playbook.

This job, however, uses the infra secret for the "openstackci" user to
update the docs.  Projects that wish to take this route require some
minor setup, but don't have to worry about managing new jobs or their
secrets and gain some benefits in having the openstackci user as a
backup admin.

To use the trigger-readthedocs-webhook job, projects will need to do
the following:

1) add openstackci user as an admin of their RTD project

2) generate an webhook via the "Integrations" dashboard page on the
   RTD project

3) provide the id from that webhook URL in job or project variables.
   This webhook id is not private; it is useless without
   authentication (it appears to be a global monotonically increasing
   integer for each webhook generated).

4) include the job. gerrit-dash-creator is populated with the new job
   for initial testing.  Other projects are currently using the
   "docs-on-readthedocs" template.  Change
   I3b65813671961d07c0a743685c537ad1df4bf68 proposes switching the
   template to use this new job.

Change-Id: Ic34ea5ead26a477a1cc5f8b25fd2ce1949c1dc13
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/579434
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/584230
'}, {'created': '2018-07-31 06:17:38.000000000', 'message': 'Add trigger-readthedocs-webhook job

   I3b65813671961d07c0a743685c537ad1df4bf68 proposes switching the

commit_message:
Add trigger-readthedocs-webhook job

This job is to trigger readthedocs via their new API

The old API was quite simple in that anyone could hit the end-point
and trigger a new build.  The v2 API now requires authentication and a
unique id for each project we wish to update.

If projects wish, they can directly use the new "trigger-readthedocs"
role (from the dependent change) and create their own jobs, providing
their username/password or webhook authentication token directly from
a secret in their project playbook.

This job, however, uses the infra secret for the "openstackci" user to
update the docs.  Projects that wish to take this route require some
minor setup, but don't have to worry about managing new jobs or their
secrets and gain some benefits in having the openstackci user as a
backup admin.

To use the trigger-readthedocs-webhook job, projects will need to do
the following:

1) add openstackci user as an admin of their RTD project

2) generate an webhook via the "Integrations" dashboard page on the
   RTD project

3) provide the id from that webhook URL in job or project variables.
   This webhook id is not private; it is useless without
   authentication (it appears to be a global monotonically increasing
   integer for each webhook generated).

4) include the job. gerrit-dash-creator is populated with the new job
   for initial testing.  Other projects are currently using the
   "docs-on-readthedocs" template.  Change
   I3b65813671961d07c0a743685c537ad1df4bf68 proposes switching the
   template to use this new job.

Change-Id: Ic34ea5ead26a477a1cc5f8b25fd2ce1949c1dc13
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/579434
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/584230

commit_message:
Remove unnecessary PlacementFixture setups

The _IntegratedTestBase functional test base class sets up the
PlacementFixture unconditionally so the deriver test class doesn't need
to do that. This patch removes the extra setups.

Change-Id: I68b939f09fdecc59ccd258595a9b80e6f42a5df1

Fix --requirements argument on quickstart.sh

parameter to --requirements-file without updating
the documentation or using a deprecation approach.

commit_message:
Fix manila update, upgrade, and FFU tasks

Manila has a similar service architecture to Cinder and the
latter has received several fixes for update, upgrade, and FFU
tasks that are missing in Manila.

Align these tasks in the Manila services with Cinder versions
of the same.

Closes-Bug: #1784032

Change-Id: Ifae95bae859a301e6bcf67910cd9140f51584bb3

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-07-11 02:05:12.000000000', 'message': "Always set a hardware architecture on uploaded images

In a multiarch environment if we have an image that doesn't have an
hw_architecture it can be scheduled on any node registered with ironic.
So this means that nova could schedule an x86_64 image on a ppc64le node
(clearly a bad thing).

Avoid that by always setting a hw_architecture image property matching
the kernel of the running system.  This is safe as in a single arch
environment, by definition all nodes are the same ;P and in a multiarch
we're being explict, which may result in NoValidHost exceptions which is
a much clearer error case than scheduling wrong ISA images.

Blueprint: multiarch-support
Change-Id: I082dfe34cf192f76f87e348aecb67e984e0c8ae9
"}, {'created': '2018-07-11 06:32:14.000000000', 'message': "Always set a hardware architecture on uploaded images

In a multiarch environment if we have an image that doesn't have an
hw_architecture it can be scheduled on any node registered with ironic.
So this means that nova could schedule an x86_64 image on a ppc64le node
(clearly a bad thing).

Avoid that by always setting a hw_architecture image property matching
the kernel of the running system.  This is safe as in a single arch
environment, by definition all nodes are the same ;P and in a multiarch
we're being explict, which may result in NoValidHost exceptions which is
a much clearer error case than scheduling wrong ISA images.

Blueprint: multiarch-support
Change-Id: I082dfe34cf192f76f87e348aecb67e984e0c8ae9
"}]
commit_message:
Always set a hardware architecture on uploaded images

In a multiarch environment if we have an image that doesn't have an
hw_architecture it can be scheduled on any node registered with ironic.
So this means that nova could schedule an x86_64 image on a ppc64le node
(clearly a bad thing).

Avoid that by always setting a hw_architecture image property matching
the kernel of the running system.  This is safe as in a single arch
environment, by definition all nodes are the same ;P and in a multiarch
we're being explict, which may result in NoValidHost exceptions which is
a much clearer error case than scheduling wrong ISA images.

Blueprint: multiarch-support
Change-Id: I082dfe34cf192f76f87e348aecb67e984e0c8ae9

commit_message:
Update/upgrade prepare/converge in config-download era

We inherit the `prepare` commands from deploy, in Rocky we will
automatically get config-download env file there so no need to
explicitly disable DeploymentSteps in *-prepare.yaml files too. We
should also disable the WorkflowSteps in config-download environment,
as they too aren't meant to be used with config-download.

Similarly, for `converge` commands in the *-converge.yaml files we
shouldn't re-enable the DeploymentSteps and WorkflowSteps, as that
would go against using config-download.

Change-Id: I89f54ba9a0a15afd26da4d4b26aba8ef09ebf04b

commit_message:
Fix publish-openstack-docs-pti check/gate html

The new publish-openstack-docs-pti template uses the openstack-tox-docs
job which does not save the rendered docs, nor does it set the job link
to the rendered documents.
This patch changes the openstack-tox-docs job to save the rendered html
and set the success-url to the rendered html documents.
This returns the behavior the publish-openstack-sphinx-docs job provided.

Change-Id: I460c00542426f6b24a7423098be9a0af14a35f01

commit_message:
WIP - Add HSTS Header to apache config for Horizon

This change adds:

Header add Strict-Transport-Security "max-age=15768000"

to the Horizon apache configuration in order to enforce that
all communications go over SSL.[0]

[0] https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/OSSN/OSSN-0035

Change-Id: I8cbc03443e3e792f50cf4ce51a78190628b1d0cd

commit_message:
Support containerized DVR in compute role

This patch adds the required parameters to the Compute role so the
agents are configured properly on upgrade.

Conflicts:
	environments/neutron-ovs-dvr.yaml

Related-Bug: #1774199
Change-Id: Iab42ae0fb13e8e92cc9903432a95e04a94a5913c
(cherry picked from commit f51f84e7818f7f70e4f6f298fff6d57509af4fbd)

commit_message:
Keycloak and Docker

* Added Keycloak to the infrastructure yaml which uses a
h2 not to complicate the installation.
* Updated the docker-compose docs.
* Move Cloud Flow image to the infrastructure yaml.

Change-Id: I2a69ca91c1638e5fd070c77ca63c8d5586887231
Signed-off-by: Vitalii Solodilov <mcdkr@yandex.ru>

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-07-09 15:34:55.000000000', 'message': 'Deprecate enable_rbac configuration option

The ``[patrole].enable_rbac`` option is deprecated and will be removed
during the "S" release. This is a legacy option that was meaningful
downstream when Patrole was a suite of tests inside Tempest itself. Now
that Patrole exists upstream as a Tempest plugin, it is paradoxical to
install the Patrole plugin yet have an option that allows all Patrole
tests to be skipped. This option is at odds with current Patrole
architecture.

To skip RBAC tests going forward, with Patrole Tempest plugin already
installed, use an appropriate regex.

Change-Id: I0cc39184c7891fb9133a45488a36ba220592915f

commit_message:
Deprecate enable_rbac configuration option

The ``[patrole].enable_rbac`` option is deprecated and will be removed
during the "S" release. This is a legacy option that was meaningful
downstream when Patrole was a suite of tests inside Tempest itself. Now
that Patrole exists upstream as a Tempest plugin, it is paradoxical to
install the Patrole plugin yet have an option that allows all Patrole
tests to be skipped. This option is at odds with current Patrole
architecture.

To skip RBAC tests going forward, with Patrole Tempest plugin already
installed, use an appropriate regex.

Change-Id: I0cc39184c7891fb9133a45488a36ba220592915f

commit_message:
Fix GlanceRegistry FFU cleanup

Instead of nooping the service we need it to run in order to
remove if from the overcloud.

Change-Id: Ide061ca5e4495495658380499c62862e43441e25
Resolves: rhbz#1562199
Closes-Bug: #1775186
(cherry picked from commit 1b6e061692eaf78e0cefcb9aa32c1ae7e7f2d5fd)

commit_message:
Add fs055 to run refstack tests

https://review.openstack.org/#/c/570719/ adds support for running
refstack tests, It will replace fs021 for the same and consumed
as a experimental job to run refstack tests.

Change-Id: I3d470dbb8b54615584f00d8a64a9ba752b36b15d

commit_message:
upgrade: move removal of services at step 3 (leftovers)

Move HAproxy, Ironic, Keystone, Zaqar and Mistral package removals at step 3
of upgrade process, required to have a successful containerized undercloud
upgrade.

Also add missing cleanup tasks for Keepalived.

This complete the work started by Ic14f7837d8d11fd5260ba7c5236018c9a6226e5e

Change-Id: I52c3aeb1a50ef0080b5411611e3f46941840f13b

commit_message:
Reduce IP address collision during port creating

Try to give it a large random chance during generate IP
address.

The DB retry mechanism change moved to neutron-lib:
I5ad139bdfb3ae125658b36d05f85f139a1b47bee

Closes-Bug: #1777968
Change-Id: I2acc9c720b39271bde2a89da4a66958f7aba5b7d
(cherry picked from commit ec5cd0d1b85d56adef836bf1167287993ec35ca6)

subject: remove lib-forward-testing tempate from neutron-lib
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 1921, 'name': 'Andrea Frittoli', 'email': 'andrea.frittoli@gmail.com', 'username': 'andrea-frittoli'}, {'_account_id': 4146, 'name': 'Clark Boylan', 'email': 'cboylan@sapwetik.org', 'username': 'cboylan'}, {'_account_id': 4694, 'name': 'Miguel Lavalle', 'email': 'miguel@mlavalle.com', 'username': 'minsel'}, {'_account_id': 5367, 'name': 'boden', 'email': 'bodenvmw@gmail.com', 'username': 'boden'}, {'_account_id': 6547, 'name': 'Andreas Jaeger', 'email': 'jaegerandi@gmail.com', 'username': 'jaegerandi'}, {'_account_id': 8556, 'name': 'Ghanshyam', 'display_name': 'Ghanshyam Mann', 'email': 'gmann@ghanshyammann.com', 'username': 'ghanshyam'}, {'_account_id': 15334, 'name': 'Stephen Finucane', 'display_name': 'stephenfin', 'email': 'stephenfin@redhat.com', 'username': 'sfinucan'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 5367, 'date': '2018-07-30 16:25:37.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2018-07-30 18:09:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

why not change lib-forward-testing template to use the new in-repo job?'}, {'account_id': 5367, 'date': '2018-07-30 18:19:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

The lib-forward-testing template is used by many other projects [1]. Not sure I feel comfortable making such a broad change that would affect all these (IIUC).


[1] http://codesearch.openstack.org/?q=lib-forward-testing&i=nope&files=&repos=project-config'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2018-07-30 18:23:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

I suggest you work with QA team and Neutron folks on doing this properly. Let's do the right thing - and not some hacks here..."}, {'account_id': 5367, 'date': '2018-07-30 18:31:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Not sure why this is a hack, nor why I'd be expected to change this across the board. My expectation was that projects would move away from their (own) legacy job(s) as time permits... As you can see in the neutron-lib patch we've actually started using tempest full instead.


Frankly I'm not sure I have the time to change this across the board. That said I guess we can just continue with the legacy job."}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2018-07-30 18:36:45.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Boden, let Neutron and QA folks chime in here - please reach out to them.

Hack means: You're just handling one case. I think you can expand this for other repos easily. We really want the *same* job used everywhere. Doing it for just a single repo is fire-fighting and not really helpful for the broader project IMHO."}, {'account_id': 5367, 'date': '2018-07-30 19:22:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

While I can certainly bring this up on the neutron side of things, it's not even clear to me why some of the projects are using this template and thus making it a topic much broader than neutron IMHO. While the person who spearheaded the job is no longer working on OpenStack, it was my understanding that the job was specific to neutron-lib's pipeline.


As an example, os-brick (and a bunch of oslo projects) is using the lib-forward-testing template in their global pipeline, but I don't even see them importing anything neutron related in their git repo so I'm not understanding why the template is used in their pipeline.



Also, while right now might be a good time for us to "roll this change out" in neutron-lib, I suspect it's not a good time for others given where we are in Rocky.'}, {'account_id': 4146, 'date': '2018-07-30 19:50:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> While I can certainly bring this up on the neutron side of things,
 > it's not even clear to me why some of the projects are using this
 > template and thus making it a topic much broader than neutron IMHO.
 > While the person who spearheaded the job is no longer working on
 > OpenStack, it was my understanding that the job was specific to
 > neutron-lib's pipeline.
 > 
 > 
 > As an example, os-brick (and a bunch of oslo projects) is using the
 > lib-forward-testing template in their global pipeline, but I don't
 > even see them importing anything neutron related in their git repo
 > so I'm not understanding why the template is used in their
 > pipeline.
 > 
 > 
 > 
 > Also, while right now might be a good time for us to "roll this
 > change out" in neutron-lib, I suspect it's not a good time for
 > others given where we are in Rocky.

The neutron in the old test job meant that the devstack install used neutron instead of nova net. Otherwise the purpose of lib forward testing was to test the master branch of libraries since by default devstack tested libraries using the most recent release. This is and was generally applicable and not neutron specific.'}, {'account_id': 5367, 'date': '2018-07-30 20:44:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Clark thanks for the history.


Unfortunately given limited background with this topic, it's still not clear to me what the suggested route forward is. From my perspective I was just trying to clean up the legacy job in neutron-lib, thinking it was the proper thing to do. Little did I know what can of worms I was opening here."}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2018-07-31 01:17:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

As per current template 'lib-forward-testing' definition I will say, you both (AJaeger and boden) have valid points. let me explain it in detail. 

Current template 'lib-forward-testing' run 'legacy-tempest-dsvm-neutron-src' job which use neutron-lib from git. This template is being used by lot of other lib repo where neutron-lib is not needed. So i agree with boden point of unnecessary using neutron-lib from LIBS_FROM_GIT for other lib than neutron-lib.

But that's not intensional or goal of this template. I will say this is half left over part and pending to fix while migrating this template to zuulv3. 

Main goal of 'lib-forward-testing' is to run the integration tests (tempest-full job) against lib proposed changes. For example whenever any change is proposed to oslo.config then, we can install few openstack services from their released version and check if proposed oslo.config change break anything there. 

This is possible if we migrate the 'lib-forward-testing' to zuulv3 and do not need to add anything as required_project (not neutron-lib which is done in current definition). The tested repo against that template run, is always taken from LIBS_FROM_GIT by devstack automatically. 
For example- 
 - when this template run against proposed change in oslo.config repo, it test integration tests with oslo.config from LIBS_FROM_GIT.
 - when this template run against proposed change in neutron-lib repo, it test integration tests with neutron-lib from LIBS_FROM_GIT.

That makes this template very general and usable across lib projects  not project only. which is what AJaeger point is to migrate the existing template to zuulv3 instead of defining separately in neutron-lib.

template can be migrated as simple as like:
- project-template:
    name: lib-forward-testing
    description: |
      Run tempest integration tests with installing the library from source
      to ensure that changes in the library do not break any of the
      services running in devstack.
    check:
      jobs:
        - tempest-full
    gate:
      jobs:
        - tempest-full

Imp point to note ^^ is we do not need to define any required_project here. 

Further if any lib or project want to define extra coverage of cross lib testing with master, they can define their own job by defining more lib/service repo as required_project. which is not any case till now.

As summary, we need to migrate the existing template to zuulv3 which you are doing in your change to neutron-lib[1] so that you will fix this template for everyone. 

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/586613/"}, {'account_id': 5367, 'date': '2018-07-31 12:34:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Ghanshyam thanks for the details; it certainly helps shed some light on the topic for non-infra folks like myself.


However as I mentioned previously, I'm not convinced this is the right time to make a change to a template used by numerous projects given where we are in Rocky. IMHO it might be better to consider this once we get Rocky out the door.


Just my $0.02."}, {'account_id': 5367, 'date': '2018-07-31 20:34:53.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

Will take this up with a broader perspective as noted in the comments once we get into dev mode for the next release.'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-07-30 16:25:37.000000000', 'message': 'remove lib-forward-testing tempate from neutron-lib

We are moving away from the legacy-tempest-dsvm-neutron-src job to an
in-project job (see depends on patch). This patch removes the
lib-forward-testing template from the neutron-lib project as well as
updates the grafana dashboard for it in favor of the new in-project job.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/586613/
Change-Id: I64ceeed44bc1341a873f2357677c93d2647f2970
'}]
commit_message:
remove lib-forward-testing tempate from neutron-lib

We are moving away from the legacy-tempest-dsvm-neutron-src job to an
in-project job (see depends on patch). This patch removes the
lib-forward-testing template from the neutron-lib project as well as
updates the grafana dashboard for it in favor of the new in-project job.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/586613/
Change-Id: I64ceeed44bc1341a873f2357677c93d2647f2970

commit_message:
Wrap interface function for multihash correctly

The store_add_to_backend_with_multihash() function was not wrapped
correctly so that Glance could consume the secure hash value.  This
patch adds the correct wrapping.

Closes-bug: #1784420

(cherry picked from commit 4d4cf1559cf393a2a10a458f83209cbeb2756e49)

Change-Id: I7a94dfffb61fc212abb58c1e1aec5884474b6aa8

commit_message:
Switch to using project-templates

In order to have more centralized configuration, switch the role
to use the project-template instead.

Also move centos check/gate to voting as it now passes.

Change-Id: I356f122a3af8d9ddbc078265b02874936b34d4fe

The failure of functional test  nova.tests.functional.test_compute_mgr.ComputeManagerTestCase.test_instance_fault_message_no_traceback_with_retry is because there is an exception after the intentional one and that's the one that is being recorded as the failure to boot.

That exception is a KeyError in abort_instance_claim of resource_tracker.py because the nodename being passed in is `None` and the only key in self.compute_nodes is 'fake-mini'. If nodename gets set to 'fake-mini' in the method the test passes fine.

So next is to dig into why abort has the wrong stuff. I'm looking into that now, but I figured it would be worthwhile reporting on the state of things to get other brains in the mix too.

This was weird to debug because of the multiple layers of decorators and other bits of indirection that are happening."}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2016-11-16 22:40:29.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2016-11-16 23:52:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Verified+1

revisions:
[{'created': '2016-11-16 16:34:55.000000000', 'message': 'rt: use a single ResourceTracker object instance

This patch removes the ResourceTracker.nodename attribute, switches the
compute manager to only create a single ResourceTracker object instance
which itself now has an in-memory dict of ComputeNode objects that are
managed by the nova-compute daemon.

This isolates the code that manages ComputeNode objects and resources in
just the resource tracker, which will make it possible for the scheduler
report client to manage Ironic nodes and custom resource classes
properly. The scheduler report client contains a cache of
ResourceProvider, Inventory, and Allocation records. We definitely did
not want to have multiple ResourceTracker object instances, each with
their own cache of ResourceProvider objects. Having a single
ResourceTracker and single scheduler report client is both more
efficient and a cleaner interface into the compute manager.

Change-Id: I6827137f35c0cb4f9fc4c6f753d9a035326ed01b
blueprint: custom-resource-classes

commit_message:
rt: use a single ResourceTracker object instance

This patch removes the ResourceTracker.nodename attribute, switches the
compute manager to only create a single ResourceTracker object instance
which itself now has an in-memory dict of ComputeNode objects that are
managed by the nova-compute daemon.

This isolates the code that manages ComputeNode objects and resources in
just the resource tracker, which will make it possible for the scheduler
report client to manage Ironic nodes and custom resource classes
properly. The scheduler report client contains a cache of
ResourceProvider, Inventory, and Allocation records. We definitely did
not want to have multiple ResourceTracker object instances, each with
their own cache of ResourceProvider objects. Having a single
ResourceTracker and single scheduler report client is both more
efficient and a cleaner interface into the compute manager.

Co-Authored-By: Chris Dent <cdent@anticdent.org>
Change-Id: I6827137f35c0cb4f9fc4c6f753d9a035326ed01b
blueprint: custom-resource-classes

messages:
[{'account_id': 27654, 'date': '2018-06-18 22:39:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 27654, 'date': '2018-06-19 03:06:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 27654, 'date': '2018-06-22 15:45:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 27654, 'date': '2018-06-25 14:35:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 5367, 'date': '2018-06-26 10:56:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 27654, 'date': '2018-06-26 21:54:26.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 27654, 'date': '2018-06-26 22:02:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 27654, 'date': '2018-06-28 21:00:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 5367, 'date': '2018-07-02 13:47:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 27654, 'date': '2018-07-03 20:29:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 5367, 'date': '2018-07-05 13:37:10.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Thank you, but why do we need more coverage here?
Are there issues slipping through that we are looking to catch with this new job/tests?


What I'm trying to understand is whats the motivation for this."}, {'account_id': 27654, 'date': '2018-07-06 15:07:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

> Thank you, but why do we need more coverage here?
 > Are there issues slipping through that we are looking to catch with
 > this new job/tests?
 > 
 > 
 > What I'm trying to understand is whats the motivation for this.

When I was working on adding 'is_filter' keyword to the resource attribute map [1], at that time I figured out I needed more jobs to verify if I missed any other attribute. That is the motivation of this patch.

However, I don't feel strong about this. Perhaps, in most of the cases, we don't need this additional job.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/575560/"}, {'account_id': 5367, 'date': '2018-07-19 21:22:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Let me ask another question. Do you think that the coverage provided by the tests in this patch is enough to remove legacy-tempest-dsvm-neutron-src??


I ask because the existing job is legacy and needs to be replaced. I'm wondering if we can just move forward with the plugin-api tests you have here and then remove the legacy job from the neutron-lib pipeline.


Any thoughts?"}, {'account_id': 27654, 'date': '2018-07-19 22:23:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

> Let me ask another question. Do you think that the coverage
 > provided by the tests in this patch is enough to remove
 > legacy-tempest-dsvm-neutron-src??
 > 
 > 
 > I ask because the existing job is legacy and needs to be replaced.
 > I'm wondering if we can just move forward with the plugin-api tests
 > you have here and then remove the legacy job from the neutron-lib
 > pipeline.
 > 
 > 
 > Any thoughts?

If you are looking for replacing the legacy job, perhaps 'tempest-full' is a good candidate because it runs a similar set of jobs as 'legacy-tempest-dsvm-neutron-src'.

About whether the tempest job can be replaced by the neutron-api job, I don't have a good answer for that. Perhaps we can consult with the neutron CI team for advice.

FWIW, below is the description about the difference of these two jobs:

==============================================
The neutron/tests/tempest/api directory was copied from the Tempest project around the Kilo timeframe. At the time, there was an overlap of tests between the Tempest and Neutron repositories. This overlap was then eliminated by carving out a subset of resources that belong to Tempest, with the rest in Neutron.

API tests that belong to Tempest deal with a subset of Neutron’s resources:

Port
Network
Subnet
Security Group
Router
Floating IP
These resources were chosen for their ubiquity. They are found in most Neutron deployments regardless of plugin, and are directly involved in the networking and security of an instance. Together, they form the bare minimum needed by Neutron.

This is excluding extensions to these resources (For example: Extra DHCP options to subnets, or snat_gateway mode to routers) that are not mandatory in the majority of cases.
==================================================="}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2018-07-25 21:15:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 5367, 'date': '2018-07-30 16:29:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

FYI I also proposed [1] to get rid of the legacy dsvm job.


In terms of landing this patch; I'm fine with it if we think it's really needed. Personally I'd think [1] would catch most everything, but maybe I'm wrong.


[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/586613/"}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2018-07-30 18:05:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2018-07-30 18:07:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 27654, 'date': '2018-07-31 19:56:04.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

Let's abandon this patch if we think the existing coverage is enough."}]

commit_message:
Add tempest api job from neutron-lib source

Introduce a non-voting job for tempest API test. This job should
help to verify pre-release neutron-lib change on the neutron
master.

Change-Id: I34b7026ad1829db492f942ec9bd2434d37df24b0

commit_message:
Update all SHAs for 16.0.17

This patch:
- updates all the roles to the latest available stable SHAs
- copies the release notes from the updated roles into the integrated repo
- updates all the OpenStack Service SHAs

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/584802/
Change-Id: I643a4e0ffb993f822e8ff64b1e298cd702bffd34

Bug report: https://bugs.launchpad.net/horizon/+bug/1777486'}, {'account_id': 25666, 'date': '2018-06-18 16:54:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

> > (2 comments)
 > 
 > Bug report: https://bugs.launchpad.net/horizon/+bug/1777486

Profiler instance is created and base_id is generated here:
 https://github.com/openstack/osprofiler/blob/master/osprofiler/profiler.py#L60

The only way to delete that is here:
 https://github.com/openstack/osprofiler/blob/master/osprofiler/profiler.py#L35

which is currently a private method. If not deleted, the old base_id will be re-used.'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2018-06-21 13:17:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(2 comments)

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-15 17:02:42.000000000', 'message': 'Delete profiler object when request completes

When a request that is being profiled completes and the response is
received, the middleware expires the profiling cookie. It also needs
to delete the profiling object that holds the base_id UUID so a new
base_id will be created for the next profile. Otherwise the same
base_id is used for subsequent queries and they become merged togther
in the database.

commit_message:
Delete profiler object when request completes

When a request that is being profiled completes and the response is
received, the middleware expires the profiling cookie. It also needs
to delete the profiling object that holds the base_id UUID so a new
base_id will be created for the next profile. Otherwise the same
base_id is used for subsequent queries and they become merged togther
in the database.

Change-Id: I379cebfa2ed5282c96df0e255a8ba04c65a8523c
Closes-Bug: #1777486
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/578362

In a jewel version, egrep -c "12.2|luminous" returns "0",
but execution will be error.
So, add pipe and echo command to make a success.

Change-Id: I94f45855f6510e747884d8b6a629a62c3d96adbd
'}]
commit_message:
Fix ceph version check error in jewel version.

In a jewel version, egrep -c "12.2|luminous" returns "0",
but execution will be error.
So, add pipe and echo command to make a success.

Change-Id: I94f45855f6510e747884d8b6a629a62c3d96adbd

commit_message:
Use ansible python api for ansible action

This review implement a callback plugin which aim to collect the
ansible result in a dedicated action.

Though we do have https://review.openstack.org/#/c/331817/1/instack_undercloud/validator.py but i don't see the equivalent here?"}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2017-12-22 18:27:06.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 3153, 'date': '2017-12-28 14:56:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Patch Set 8 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 7144, 'date': '2018-01-03 22:44:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9: Code-Review-1

i'm not really in favor of this. we've had significant issues with non qualified hostnames in the past.

even though this passes CI, that only covers a fraction of real world use cases.

i don't see any compelling reason left in the commit message or bug as to why this change is actually needed. Just use a fully qualified hostname."}, {'account_id': 13039, 'date': '2018-01-05 11:18:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 2011, 'date': '2018-01-12 00:11:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 9:

So the issue is that we are creating entries in /etc/hosts via puppet the same way you would if you were installing the overcloud.  These then conflict with entries in the hosts file given to us from infra.  I'm sure there's a better way to fix this but for now we're using this workaround."}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2018-07-31 19:05:51.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

commit_message:
Allow non fully qualified hostnames for undercloud

The validation checks that the hostname (fully qualified or not) is
present in the /etc/hosts file and adds it to /etc/hosts otherwise.

Previously the _check_hostname() function would raise an exception if
it had to write the hostname to /etc/hosts and it was not fully
qualified.

This patch make it accept non fully qualified hostnames to match the
actual check.

Closes-Bug: #1737356
Change-Id: I56f886d45de5933fe8438580ff9144edb02009e8
Co-Authored-By: Wes Hayutin <weshay@redhat.com>
Co-Authored-By: Martin André <m.andre@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Add progress bar for image uploads

This patch adds new option "--progress" to
"openstack overcloud image upload", which enables
uploading progress bar output in the CLI.

Change-Id: I690b32a6eedd949fadea5290896801bfaaac76ce
Partial-bug: #1735465

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-06-26 19:31:41.000000000', 'message': "Fix comment about https redirect for horizon proxy

Since we now redirect all non-SSL connections to https for horizon,
update the comment preceding the redirect rule to be accurate.

Change-Id: I4347ef9cb443ed0b9b2f49b71446ad206359dbea
Signed-off-by: Ryan O'Hara <rohara@redhat.com>
"}]
commit_message:
Fix comment about https redirect for horizon proxy

Since we now redirect all non-SSL connections to https for horizon,
update the comment preceding the redirect rule to be accurate.

Change-Id: I4347ef9cb443ed0b9b2f49b71446ad206359dbea
Signed-off-by: Ryan O'Hara <rohara@redhat.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2016-11-14 16:32:07.000000000', 'message': 'Stop openvswitch service before running yum update

Postrscript in upgrade of openvswitch-2.4.0-1.el7 makes br-ctlplane
IP disappear.

Change-Id: Id00e1a4e4c84ad7cb4d3a61a6517292a34d8fce3
Closes-Bug: 1635205
Resolves: rhbz#1364540
'}]
commit_message:
Stop openvswitch service before running yum update

Postrscript in upgrade of openvswitch-2.4.0-1.el7 makes br-ctlplane
IP disappear.

Change-Id: Id00e1a4e4c84ad7cb4d3a61a6517292a34d8fce3
Closes-Bug: 1635205
Resolves: rhbz#1364540

This will break our current upgrade flow (actually it may not because we already run a package update during undercloud install, but that being the case this is at best an unnecessary change).

https://bugs.launchpad.net/tripleo/+bug/1635205

The issue is that our workflow if wrong here, now we need to deliver workaround into python-tripleoclient instead of patching puppet that should be (code is present there) taking care of updating all the packages. If we want to update any package here than it should only be the instack-undercloud. Instack undercloud should update puppet and it's dependencies and puppet should take care of rest."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2016-11-14 17:05:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

Build succeeded (check-tripleo pipeline).

- gate-tripleo-ci-centos-7-ovb-ha http://logs.openstack.org/76/327176/4/check-tripleo/gate-tripleo-ci-centos-7-ovb-ha/b8531cb/ : SUCCESS in 2h 30m 30s
- gate-tripleo-ci-centos-7-ovb-nonha http://logs.openstack.org/76/327176/4/check-tripleo/gate-tripleo-ci-centos-7-ovb-nonha/52e6c94/ : SUCCESS in 2h 19m 22s'}, {'account_id': 8449, 'date': '2016-11-15 11:29:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

two things after a quick chat just now with lucas... this isn't intended for Newton. i.e. it doesn't fix an issue we have in testing it is a new for Ocata thing.

Lucas filed this bug a while back https://bugs.launchpad.net/tripleo/+bug/1630249 which seems related."}, {'account_id': 7065, 'date': '2016-11-15 14:24:53.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

> two things after a quick chat just now with lucas... this isn't
 > intended for Newton. i.e. it doesn't fix an issue we have in
 > testing it is a new for Ocata thing.
 > 
 > Lucas filed this bug a while back https://bugs.launchpad.net/tripleo/+bug/1630249
 > which seems related.

I still don't understand why you wouldn't update the client too. The client is the main entrypoint, not instack-undercloud. By this, I mean you install python-tripleoclient in order to install the undercloud on a fresh machine. Therefore, that should be the updated package, not instack-undercloud."}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2017-01-19 21:09:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Verified-1

This change or one of its cross-repo dependencies was unable to be automatically merged with the current state of its repository. commit_message:
Don't update whole system on undercloud upgrade

We should update only instack-undercloud package and that should
 take care of any necessary package update.

Depends-On: I747251e17b85c677dd4500a558f1d87b33cb3e5f
Change-Id: I88c23cf28f21085ad6b3cce5d2830f97e517fc84

commit_message:
Remove workaround for openstack-nova-api

We should no longer need to restart nova api service after upgrading
undercloud.

Change-Id: I8a91707323b2caa140528205dca8f78117efccc2

commit_message:
Sync xWorker count description to match new derived defaults

The description text for the neutron related worker counts is no longer
accurate as the puppet defined default is now based on ::os_workers.

Change-Id: Ibb251c1bb24719ce16f8172b4c8ebca8e920f2c6
Depends-On: Ic90461e7d843edf07d884d6717a2dd3e68664b24
